Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2013 05:27PM bean wrote: I just had my MRI today. Hated it. I should find out Monday what the results are. I had a us guided biopsy in January. Came back benign fibroadenoma, two of them. Honestly, I'd rather have another biopsy than an MRI. I could not have been able to stay in that thing for a minute longer. Next time, I take a Xanax for sure. I hope all comes out well for you!
Posts.Title: MRI kk12903 meghar

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2013 01:34PM bean wrote: Thanks for the well wishes.   :) I hope the scan proves that the issue is just an old injury. It's always good to be prepared for the worst, though. It's not that I'm a negative person or that I always think the worse, but I just want to be ready in case they say those two words to me. I'm sure there will still be an element of shock if that's the case, but I am prepared to fight if I have to. KK & Raysnbucs: Hugs to you both! Let us know how it goes. Brenda
Posts.Title: MRI kk12903 meghar

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2013 07:37PM bean wrote: Ladies ~ You are all a true inspiration! I know that sounds so cliche, but there are no other words for it. I joined BCO in January due to a little scare about a "thickening" on my mamo. I had a biopsy and it's b9. I have an MRI coming in late March. Now, I'm back to this website for a much bigger scare . . . My sister was dx 9 years ago with ILC. Even back then it had already metastisized to an area in her abdomen (I'm not sure exactly where). She had a hystorectomy, chemo, radiation, and I'm sure she was given drugs but I'm not sure what. She was been declared "in remission" after a year. Although she has had a lot of pain in her legs, she has been living life for the last 8 years as a widow raising two boys. Last week, she (finally) went to the ER after a month of vomiting  after eating large or fatty meals. They found a "blockage" in her colon. Surgery confirmed that it was a BC met. Before her surgery and during all the tests the hospital was giving her, an MRI also found two "bone lesions". We are already convinced that these are mets as well. My sister says she's prepared to fight and go through treatment once again. She is still in the hospital recovering from her surgery and will probably go home in a few days; once she's able to have a BM. Her ONC has not yet seen her because she is still in the hospital's care. She's hospitalized for her "blockage", not her cancer treatment. She will see her ONC once she released from the hospital. Obviously, I am beside myself with fear . . . Fear that she may not make it for even another year. I know now that she was lucky to have already made it 9 years with metastisized BC. Her boys are now 18 and 19 years old, but they still need her! She's everything to them. I will soon have the opportunity to speak with her ONC. Even though he has not yet seen my sister, he does have all the recent test results and reports. My question to all of you: What questions should I ask the ONC when I talk to him? I can only think to ask what he thinks her prognosis is, or how long he thinks the cancer was there. Can anyone please give me some advice to the information I should try to get from him? Also, has anyone here ever have mets to their colon or bones? Thank you in advance for any advice or info you can give me. Blessings to each and everyone one of you lovely ladies!
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2013 09:19AM bean wrote: Chickadee ~ Thank you so much for your response. Yes, I've done what you all say not to do and I've been to Dr. Google. I know that her prognosis MAY not be good, but I am not taking that to heart and I'm not sharing the information with anyone. I don't want to scare anyone and I also know that my sister's case is her case and no one else's. She has already beat the odds by far. I've also learned that she's got positive things going for her. Those who have bones mets generally do better than those with mets on other organs. I'm not sure if the colon counts as a "other organ". Her cancer is also estrogen receptive and therefore grows slower (I think), and her hysterectomy helps with that as well. She also went a fairly long time before her relapse which, as I understand it, helps her longevity. I want nothing but to help her. Unfortunately, I'm 3000 miles away from her and can't help her as much as I'd like to. My mom, who also lives in another state and lived with her for a year when she was diagnosed the first time, is going back to her next week. I thank God that my mom can be there to take care of her, but I also hate to see all of this put on my mom and that my dad is being left home alone. Both my parents are in great shape, but they're getting older. I am going there for a week at the end of March, but I just wish I could be there the whole time to help her. Thanks for listening . . . and thanks for the advice. I promise not to hound her with anything. I will be there for her (although 3000 miles away) and make sure she knows that she is loved very much.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2013 07:46PM - edited Feb 27, 2013 07:48PM by bean Hi Mel ~ Yes, it is an ILC met in my sister's colon. I have not heard from anyone else on this website that this has happened to, but I'm curious as well. I hope you find the answers you're looking for.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: bean wrote: I had my annual mamo a couple weeks ago which showed "possible abnormalities". Yesterday I went in for more mamo pics and an unltrasound. Nothing was seen on the new mamo pics. Two areas were seen on the ultrasound although she told me that it's not the same thing they saw on the first mamo. So, the doctor is "almost positive" these are firbroadenoma and she recomends waiting 6 months to see if they change. This is were I'm confused . . . I'm 43. My sister, who is now 50, had invasive BC diagnosed when she was 41. My grandmother also had breast cancer. Because of my family history, I would assume that I would be considered high-risk, but they say that I'm not. I have read that fibroadenomas can be confused for cancer from ultrasound pics, so I'm surprised by the doctor's recommendation. Also, it's more common for a younger woman to develope fibroadenoma. And, I read somewhere that fibroadenomas are usually 1.5cm at least, and the larger of my two lumps is only 5mm! Despite what she thinks, I am having them biopsied in a couple weeks. I told myself that I'm not going to worry unless I have to, but I can't help it. Everything that I read tells me this is NOT fibroadenoma: It's much smaller than 1.5cm, I have a very close family history, and usually younger women get firbroadenoma. Can anyone give me some opinions? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Why am I not high-risk? bean bean

Posts.Content: bean wrote: I had an "abnormality" on my mamo on Dec 26. I had an ultrasound on Jan 4 that showed two tumors in a different location than this "abnormality". I opted for a biopsy (Jan 17) that came back benign. The tumors are fibroadenoma. Yesterday, I had an MRI . . . I'm nervous about the results which I get on Monday. I just felt weird when the screening was over. The nurse (Mary) that did my MRI was wonderful. She was very friendly, talkative and explained everything before and halfway into my test. Suddenly, she stopped talking so much. After my test, she didn't even come out of the little room that she and the other nurse were sitting in while I was in the MRI machine. The other nurse was the one to get me up and ready to go home. I never saw Mary again after that except through the glass upon leaving the room. She didn't look at me or say goodbye. I just thought that was odd. Another reason I'm worried is I THINK my lymph nodes under my right arm are swollen. I don't know if I'm over reacting or if they're even really swollen. I know I can feel them and they are a little tender. Does that mean they're swollen? Can you normally feel your lymph nodes anyway? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Lymph Nodes Swollen? bean bean

Hoping that mamo is here sooner than later.  :)

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2013 07:51AM bean wrote: Deanna~ Thanks so much for your info. I haven't made it through the breast center at our hospital. So, the doctor I'm speaking about it the radiologist that saw my mamo and US pics and did a little US on me as well. I didn't meet her until after my second mamo and after the technologist did my ultrasound. I wasn't happy with her because she seemed to just assume she wasn't going to find anything on me rather than trying to find something. I did make sure that when I go in for my biopsy, I will have a different doctor. I want to get the biopsy in any case; even if a surgeon believes I don't need one. My sister had invasive lobular carcinoma which I learned can sometimes be tricky to see on ultrasound. I also read something about cancer developing around fibroadenoma. I am going to ask them to biopsy the surrounding area. I also want a rescan in 6 months. I also plan to speak to a breast surgeon (my gynecologist refer me to) and see what he thinks. Thank you for the link. I will certainly look into that! AND find out what my Bi-Rad rating is. The breast center is supposed to be a good one. Anyway, they base their high risk determination on a formula that they use. I have actually found similiar formulas on-line and according to them, I'm not high risk either. It's because I started my period later than most (14) and had kids earlier than most (23). I think if you have a first degree relative that was dx, it should null any of the other "factors". Thanks again!   Brenda
Posts.Title: Why am I not high-risk? bean bean

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2013 01:23PM bean wrote: Exactly. I don't trust their so-called high-risk fomula. Not only did my sister have breast cancer, but so did my Aunt on my mom's side and my paternal grandmother. And, you right, anyone with breast is at risk. I don't find it hard to believe that it can happen to me. Although my sister is 7 years older than me, we are very much alike; body type and life-style. I don't want to worry, but I just have a sinking feeling. I am going to call a breast surgeon first thing tomorrow. Thanks again

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2013 11:07AM bean wrote: Hi Nesw ~ My experiance sounds a little similiar to the beginnings of yours. My first mamo showed a "density" on the left back area of my left breast. My second, diagnostic mamo, showed nothing of concern. During my ultrasound, the radiologist found what she was "almost positive" is two fibroadenoma, however she said these weren't what showed on the first mamo although they are in the same general area. My sister had invasive lobular carcinoma, which is hard to pick up in mamos and ultrasounds because it normally doesn't form a lump. It grows more like a spidar web and looks like a density. The more I read, the more I'm not too concerned about the fibroadenoma, but am scared of this ILC. I'm afraid they will miss a cancer in that might be in the surounding area. Thank you so much for sharing your story. I feel a little like I'm not being taken seriously, at least not by the one doctor I have seen so far. I plan to call a breast surgeon tomorrow and see if I can't get an MRI or a biopsy of more area.
